choices.text: Toynbee’s test uses positive pressure to assess Eustachian tube patency
Saccharine test evaluates the ventilatory function of the Eustachian tube
Tympanometry evaluates the ability of the tube to equilibrate pressure during swallowing
Valsalva test should always be used in children to diagnose tube dysfunction

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Eustachian tube function tests is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tympanometry evaluates the ability of the tube to equilibrate pressure during swallowing

 

Multiple clinical and diagnostic tests are available to evaluate ventilatory, protective, and clearance functions of the Eustachian tube (ET):

 

Tympanometry (Inflation–deflation test)

 

  • Assesses pressure regulation function of ET
  • Positive and negative pressures are applied in the external ear canal
  • Patient swallows → Tube opens → Pressure equalizes
  • Normal response = TM compliance returns to baseline

 

Toynbee’s Test

 

  • Assesses negative pressure generation
  • Patient swallows with nose pinched → inward movement of TM if tube is functional
  • Physiological maneuver

 

Valsalva Maneuver

 

  • Builds positive pressure by forced expiration against closed nose and mouth
  • Can push air into the middle ear if ET is patent
  • Not preferred in children due to difficulty in performance

 

Saccharine/Methylene Blue Test

 

  • Assesses clearance function via taste or dye detection in throat
  • Requires pre-existing TM perforation

 

Sonotubometry

 

  • Non-invasive method under development
  • Assesses active opening and duration of tube patency using sound signals

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Toynbee’s test uses positive pressure to assess Eustachian tube patency: Incorrect. Toynbee’s test uses negative pressure, not positive.

 

Option B. Saccharine test evaluates the ventilatory function of the Eustachian tube: Incorrect. Saccharine test evaluates clearance, not ventilation.

 

Option D. Valsalva test should always be used in children to diagnose tube dysfunction: Incorrect. Valsalva is not reliable in children; Politzer test preferred.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tympanometry evaluates the Eustachian tube's ability to equilibrate middle ear pressure during swallowing by assessing tympanic membrane compliance.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 59

choices.text: Infant Eustachian tube is narrower and longer
Infant Eustachian tube is more angulated and rigid
Infant Eustachian tube is shorter, wider, and more horizontal
Infant Eustachian tube has more elastic recoil and better closure

questions.text: A 1-year-old child presents with recurrent episodes of otitis media. The pediatrician advises the mother to feed the child in an upright position. What is the most likely anatomical reason for this advice?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Infant Eustachian tube is shorter, wider, and more horizontal

 

The Eustachian tube in infants differs significantly from adults, predisposing them to middle ear infections:

 

 

  • These differences make it easier for milk/feed to reflux into the middle ear when the baby is lying flat.
  • This regurgitation leads to recurrent otitis media, especially in bottle-fed infants.
  • Upright feeding helps reduce reflux and middle ear contamination.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Infant Eustachian tube is narrower and longer: Infant ET is shorter, not longer

 

Option B. Infant Eustachian tube is more angulated and rigid. It is less angulated and flaccid, not rigid

 

Option D. Infant Eustachian tube has more elastic recoil and better closure: Elastic recoil is ineffective in infants, leading to poor tube closure

 

Educational Objective:

 

Infant Eustachian tubes are shorter, wider, and more horizontal, making them prone to regurgitation and otitis media; upright feeding can help prevent this.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 58

choices.text: Clearance of middle ear secretions via mucociliary action
Protection of middle ear from nasopharyngeal pressure and secretions
Equalization of pressure across tympanic membrane
Continuous drainage of perilymph from the inner ear

questions.text: Which of the following is not a function of the Eustachian tube?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Continuous drainage of perilymph from the inner ear

 

The Eustachian tube plays a crucial role in the physiology of the middle ear, not the inner ear. It performs three key functions:

 

1. Ventilation (Pressure Equalization)

 

  • Maintains equal air pressure on both sides of the tympanic membrane
  • Opens during swallowing, yawning, sneezing
  • Poor function leads to negative/positive middle ear pressure, impairing hearing
  • Less efficient in supine position, infants, or during sleep

 

2. Protection

 

  • Prevents entry of:
    • Excessive nasopharyngeal sound pressure
    • Reflux of secretions from nasopharynx
  • This protective function is impaired in:
    • Patulous ET
    • Short, wide tubes in infants
    • TM perforation
    • Forceful nose blowing, nasal obstruction, or adenoids

 

3. Clearance

 

  • Lined by ciliated columnar epithelium (especially anterior middle ear + ET)
  • Cilia beat toward nasopharynx
  • Helps in clearing secretions/debris from middle ear
  • Aided by active opening and closing of the ET

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clearance of middle ear secretions via mucociliary action: True function.  Clearance via mucociliary action

 

Option B. Protection of middle ear from nasopharyngeal pressure and secretions: True function. Protection from nasopharyngeal pressure/secretions

 

Option C. Equalization of pressure across tympanic membrane: True function: Pressure equalization for optimal tympanic membrane vibration

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Eustachian tube ventilates the middle ear, protects it from nasopharyngeal secretions and pressure, and clears secretions via mucociliary action.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 58

choices.text: It develops from the first branchial cleft and is 36 cm long
The isthmus is its widest part and lies at the nasopharyngeal end
It makes a 45-degree angle with the horizontal and opens into the nasopharynx at the torus tubarius
It is 24 mm long, entirely cartilaginous, and connects middle ear to oropharynx

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the Eustachian tube is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It makes a 45-degree angle with the horizontal and opens into the nasopharynx at the torus tubarius

 

The Eustachian tube (auditory tube or pharyngotympanic tube):

 

  • Length: ~36 mm (not cm)
    • Outer 12 mm = bony part
    • Inner 24 mm = cartilaginous part
  • Isthmus: Narrowest part of the tube located at the junction between bony and cartilaginous parts
  • Angle: Makes a ~45° angle with the horizontal plane
  • Embryological origin: From the first pharyngeal pouch (not cleft, not arch)
  • Opens into: Nasopharynx, marked by a mucosal elevation called the torus tubarius

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It develops from the first branchial cleft and is 36 cm long: Incorrect. Develops from first pouch, not cleft; also it is 36 mm, not cm.

 

Option B. The isthmus is its widest part and lies at the nasopharyngeal end: Incorrect. The isthmus is the narrowest part, not the widest, and it's not at the nasopharyngeal end.

 

Option D. It is 24 mm long, entirely cartilaginous, and connects middle ear to oropharynx: Incorrect. Only 24 mm is cartilaginous; it connects to nasopharynx, not oropharynx.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Eustachian tube is 36 mm long, develops from the first pharyngeal pouch, forms a 45° angle with the horizontal, and opens into the nasopharynx at the torus tubarius.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 57

choices.text: Otitis media with effusion
Patulous Eustachian tube
Acute Eustachian tube obstruction
Tympanic membrane perforation

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman in her third trimester of pregnancy complains of hearing her own voice and breathing sounds loudly in one ear. On otoscopy, tympanic membrane movements are noted with respiration. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Patulous Eustachian tube

 

Patulous Eustachian tube (ET):

 

  • The ET is normally closed and opens only during swallowing, yawning, or chewing via tensor veli palatini, levator veli palatini, and salpingopharyngeus muscles
  • In patulous ET, the tube remains abnormally open, leading to:
    • Autophony (hearing one's own voice)
    • Audible breathing sounds
    • Tympanic membrane movements visible on otoscopy — inward with inspiration and outward with expiration
  • Common causes:
    • Rapid weight loss
    • 3rd trimester of pregnancy
    • Multiple sclerosis
  • Treatment:
    • Usually not needed for acute cases
    • Options in chronic cases: weight gain, oral potassium iodide, ET cauterization, or grommet insertion

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Otitis media with effusion: Presents with hearing loss, fullness, and fluid level, but not autophony or visible respiratory TM movements.

 

Option C. Acute ET obstruction: Typically causes negative middle ear pressure, not autophony.

 

Option D. TM perforation: Can cause hearing loss and whistling sound, but not synchronized TM movements with respiration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patulous Eustachian tube presents with autophony and visible tympanic membrane movement with respiration, and is often seen in pregnancy or after weight loss.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 57
